contentrichtext.text: {{Coord|21|34|31|N|158|16|57|W|display=title}} [[File:Kaena Point Aerial.jpg|thumb|Aerial photo of Ka{{okina}}ena from the West]] [[File:Kaena Pt.jpg|thumb|Ka{{okina}}ena Point as seen from Kāneana on the south shore near Mākua Cave]] [[File:Kaena Trail.JPG|thumb|Panorama of the Ka{{okina}}ena Point Trailhead, as seen from the east side of O'ahu, past Mokule'ia Beach in 2013]] '''Ka{{okina}}ena''' or '''Kaena Point''' is the westernmost tip of land on the island of [[Oahu|O{{okina}}ahu]]. The point can be reached on foot from both the East (via O{{okina}}ahu's North Shore / [[Mokuleia, Hawaii|Mokulē{{okina}}ia]]) and Southeast (via Wai{{okina}}anae Coast). An unimproved track extends some {{convert|3|mi|km}} along the coast from the end of the paved road on the east side, where a gate prevents entry of all except authorized vehicles.On the southeast side, at '''Ka{{okina}}ena State Park''', a paved road passes a beach before terminating into an unpaved road. It continues for a few miles, after which the road is washed out, and further travel must be on foot. It is not possible to travel around the point in a vehicle as the route is better described as a "path" in most places, and is lined on one side with a cliff and on the other with [[basalt]] rocks which are quite capable of damaging vehicles. In [[Hawaiian language|Hawaiian]], ''ka{{okina}}ena'' means 'the heat'. The area was named after a brother or cousin of [[Pele (Goddess)|Pele]] who accompanied her from ''Kahiki''. The [[Hawaii|State of Hawai{{okina}}i]] has designated the point as a Natural Area Reserve to protect nesting Laysan Albatrosses and wedge-tailed Shearwaters, Hawaiian monk seals, and the fragile (to vehicular traffic) native strand vegetation that has been restored there. Some ancient Hawaiian folklore states that Ka{{okina}}ena Point is the "jumping-off" point for souls leaving this world.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://hawaii.gov/dlnr/dofaw/nars/reserves/oahu/kaenapoint |title = Ka'ena Point |publisher = State of Hawaii |accessdate = 2013-03-18}}</ref> During the winter months, O{{okina}}ahu's North Shore is typically bombarded by large, powerful waves that attract [[Surfing|surfers]] from around the world. It is rumored that Ka{{okina}}ena Point typically has waves (up to {{convert|15|m|ft|disp=or}} in height) larger than those at Waimea Bay, one of O{{okina}}ahu's world-famous surfing locations. This has not been confirmed; however, during the famous "Swell Of The Century" in 1969 and on the day of [[Greg Noll]]'s famous wave at Mākaha, Greg himself took a picture of a gigantic wave breaking at Ka{{okina}}ena Point. Until "Biggest Wednesday" on 28 January 1998, when professional surfer [[Ken Bradshaw]] was photographed riding a wave with a reported {{convert|85|ft|m|adj=on}} face, it was believed that Noll's picture showed the largest wave ever photographed. During that famous swell in January 1998, several persons reported seeing waves with {{convert|60|-|80|ft|m|adj=on}} faces at Ka{{okina}}ena Point. Despite these reports, Ka{{okina}}ena Point does not have the popularity with surfers of other North Shore locations. Ka{{okina}}ena Point is located in a very remote area with no direct paved road access and no rescue capabilities. Additionally, the Point's geography results in [[undertow (wave action)|undertows]], dangerous [[rip current]]s and other hazardous ocean conditions that make any water activity highly dangerous. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|1=http://www.hawaiistateparks.org/parks/oahu/index.cfm?park_id=19}} {{Protected Areas of Hawaii}} [[Category:Headlands of Hawaii]] [[Category:State parks of Hawaii]] [[Category:Landforms of Oahu]] [[Category:Protected areas of Oahu]]
